record_data.record_plain_text: EXHIBIT "A" DESCRIPTION OF PLANT The Southern Electric Generating Company has acquired a site in Shelby County, Alabama and will construct thereon a steam-electric generating station and a step-up substation. The plant is located on the west bank of the Coosa River between the confluence of Yellowleaf Creek and the Coosa River. It is approximately one and one-half miles northeast of the town of Wilsonville, Alabama. The Southern Electric Generating Company proposes to acquire rights-of-way in Alabama and to construct thereon transmission lines as required from its generating station to the Georgia State Line. Such other transmission lines as are required by Georgia Power Company and by Alabama Power Company will be constructed by those companies. The steam-electric generating station will be of conventional indoor type construction, with concrete substructure resting on rock foundations and with superstructure walls of corrugated asbestos or equivalent material. General facilities to be provided, in addition to the main power house and step-up substation, will be those essential for a new plant on a new site, and will include: site improvements; access roadways; railroad sidings for delivery of coal, equipment and materials; coal and ash handling facilities; fire protection system; service and make-up water facilities; sanitary system; service and machine shop facilities and any other miscellaneous buildings and/or components required for a generating station of the type and size contemplated. The initial installation will consist of four (4) units each having a maximum net generating capability of approximately 250,000 KW. The first three units are under construction and will be completed in 1960 and 1961, and it is presently contemplated that one unit will be added in the year 1962. The site is believed to have a potential ultimate capability of 1,500,000 KW, or more, and the layout will be such as to permit the subsequent installation of a fifth and a sixth unit equal to or larger than the initial units. The turbogenerators will be installed crosswise of the turbine room with their steam ends facing the boiler room and will be located on the operating floor level at elevation 424 feet. Two (2) overhead traveling cranes, each of 100 tons capacity, will be provided for installing and servicing the turbo-generators and other auxiliaries located in the turbine and condenser room areas. The boiler room will parallel the generator room and will be located nearest to the Coosa River. The operating floor level of the boiler room will also be at elevation 424 feet, with the ash pit floor at elevation 387.0 feet. The condenser pit floor will be at elevation 384.0 feet. The yard area will be graded to elevation 422 feet and any elevation below this will be sub-grade. Turbine and boiler control will be provided for each pair of units in one room, located at operating floor level and in the area between the turbines and boilers. The electrical controls for the generators, substation, etc. will be housed in a separate room located on the substation side of the turbine room and of sufficient size to accommodate the controls for all units in the plant. The condenser cooling water system will be arranged to take water into the plant form Yellowleaf Creek and to discharge it to the Coosa River. Separate intake and discharge tunnels will be provided for each pair of units. Each of the first three turbo-generators in the initial installation will be cross-compound design. Steam conditions will be 2000 psig 1000 F. at the throttle, with reheat at 1000 F. The surface condensers will be two-pass divided water box type, designed to maintain 2.07" Hg back pressure with inlet cooling water temperature of 80 F. for the first two units and a tandem twin shell double flow type, designed to maintain 1.85" Hg back pressure with an inlet cooling water temperature of 80 F. for the third unit, when operating at maximum design capability. The feedwater system will consist of six heaters, one of which will be a deaerating type. Three half-capacity boiler feed pumps with hydraulic couplings and constant speed motor drives are installed with each unit. Each boiler will have a maximum continuous rating of 1,700,000 lbs. per hour and will be designed for pulverized coal firing of coal secured from either Warrior or Cahaba coal field sources. Coal will be delivered by rail and/or possibly by truck). Two separate unloading and conveyor transport systems, properly interconnected, will be installed, together with necessary storage and reclaiming facilities. Conventional draft systems will be provided, with electrical dust collectors and with separate concrete chimneys (250 feet high, above grade) to serve each boiler. Each generator will have a maximum capability of 320,000 Kva (two shafts) at 30 psig hydrogen pressure, with separate motor driven exciters. Generator voltage will be 15 Kv. The principal source of station service power supply will be at 4.16 Kv, with a second source (for the smaller auxiliaries and services) at 0.60 Kv. The two generators of a cross-compound unit will be connected to the 230 Kv switchyard through one 3-phase step-up transformer of 300,000 Kva capacity. Two 3-phase auxiliary transformers of 10,000/12,500 Kva capacity will be installed with each of the first two units and two 8,500/10,620 Kva, 3-phase transformers with the third unit to furnish the stations auxiliary power requirements. One or more starting transformers will be provided. For the first three-unit installation (to be completed in 1960 and 1961), two 230 Kv lines to the Georgia Power Company system and two 230 Kv lines to the Alabama Power Company system will be constructed. Additional transmission will be provided as required by subsequent capacity additions. Although the bulk of the transmission is expected to be at 230 Kv, the substation layout will anticipate the possible requirement for a limited amount of 115 Kv transmission into Alabama. The estimated cost of the initial installation of four units (approximately 1,000,000 KW) is as follows: Plant site $ 500,000 Units 1 & 2, including substation 69,200,000 Unit 3, including substation 31,800,000 Unit 4, including substation 31,800,000 General Administrative Expenses 400,000 Total - Four (4) Unit Plant $133,700,000

Rate Schedule No. 1
Power Contract
Between
Southern Electric Generating Company,
Alabama Power Company
And
Georgia Power Company

POWER CONTRACT Southern Electric Generating Company Alabama Power Company Georgia Power Company THIS AGREEMENT, made as of the 27th day of January, 1959, between SOUTHERN ELECTRIC GENERATING COMPANY (hereinafter call "SEGCO"), an Alabama Corporation; ALABAMA POWER COMPANY (hereinafter call "Alabama"), an Alabama Corporation; and GEORGIA POWER COMPANY (hereinafter called "Georgia"), a Georgia Corporation; WITNESSETH WHEREAS, Alabama provides electric service throughout a large portion of the State of Alabama adjacent to the territory served by Georgia in the State of Georgia; and WHEREAS, Georgia provides electric service throughout a large portion of the State of Georgia adjacent to the territory served by Alabama in the State of Alabama; and WHEREAS, Alabama will require additional electric capacity and energy to supply its customers in the State of Alabama, and Georgia will require additional electric capacity and energy to supply its customers in the State of Georgia; and WHEREAS, it is to the mutual advantage of Alabama and Georgia to provide additional electric capacity and energy to serve their customers in the aforesaid areas from a single steam electric generating plant; and WHEREAS, SEGCO proposes to construct a steam electric generating plant on the Coosa River near Wilsonville, Alabama, having an initial installed capacity of 450,000 kilowatts, consisting of two 225,000 kilowatt units which are planned to be placed in operation during the second quarter of 1960, subject to delays beyond the control of SEGCO; and WHEREAS, SEGCO presently contemplates that the capacity of the aforesaid steam electric generating plant will be increased to about 1,000,000 kilowatts by the installation of two additional units in 1961 and 1962 of approximately the same size as the first two units; and WHEREAS, SEGCO owns coal and coal rights in the Cahaba and Warrior coal fields and intends to construct and operate, or cause to be constructed and operated, mines to provide a portion or all the coal required to operate its aforesaid steam electric generating plant; and WHEREAS, SEGCO proposes to construct two single circuit 230 kilovolt transmission lines from the high voltage bus of its aforesaid steam electric generating plant to the Alabama-Georgia state line for the purpose of transmitting electric capacity and energy for delivery to Georgia at said state line and may construct such additional transmission lines for such purpose from time to time as may be necessary or desirable; and WHEREAS, Alabama proposes to construct a single circuit 230 kilovolt transmission line connecting with the high voltage bus of aforesaid stem electric generating plant for the purpose of transmitting electric capacity and energy into its system and may construct additional transmission lines for such purpose from time to time as may be necessary or desirable; and WHEREAS, SEGCO, in order to finance in part the construction of the aforesaid steam electric generating plant, transmission lines and coal mines, proposes to issue and sell, from time to time, its first mortgage bonds to be issued under and secured by an indenture of mortgage between SEGCO and a trustee or trustees; and WHEREAS, Alabama is desirous of purchasing electric capacity and energy from the aforesaid plant under terms and conditions hereinafter set forth; and WHEREAS, Georgia is desirous of purchasing electric capacity and energy from the aforesaid plant under terms and conditions hereinafter set forth; and WHEREAS, SEGCO is able and willing to supply Alabama and Georgia electric capacity and energy from the aforesaid plant under terms and conditions hereinafter set forth; NOW, THEREFORE, in consideration of the above premises and of mutual benefits from the covenants herein set forth, the parties hereto do hereby agree as follows: ARTICLE I FACILITIES TO BE PROVIDED Section 1.01 Generating Station: SEGCO will construct and operate a steam electric generating plant on the Coosa River near Wilsonville, Alabama presently contemplated to consist of four turbo generator units and associated boilers together with condensers, pumps, fans, and other necessary auxiliary equipment, step-up substation, and switching facilities, said plant being referred to hereinafter as "Plant"; and SEGCO agrees to exert its best efforts to have the first unit in commercial operation by May 31, 1960, and the second unit in commercial operation by June 30, 1960. It is contemplated that the third and fourth units will be installed during 1961 and 1962, respectively. SEGCO agrees to make available to Alabama and Georgia all the electric capacity and energy available from the Plant in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement. Section 1.02 Description of Plant: A description of Plant, together with estimated costs of construction, is contained in Exhibit "A" hereto attached and made a part hereof. SEGCO agrees that it will make no substantial departure from plans for such Plant as set forth in said Exhibit "A" unless agreed to by Alabama and by Georgia. Section 1.03 Construction of Additional Capacity: Generating capacity in addition to that described in Sections 1.01 and 1.02 may be constructed by SEGCO and such added capacity shall, if mutually agreed to by the parties to this Agreement, be included under the provisions of this Agreement and, in such event, such added capacity, and all related facilities (exclusive of property included within the terms "Transmission Lines" and "Coal Mines" as hereinafter defined), shall, as the same is added, be included with the term "Plant." Section 1.04 Maintenance of the Equipment: SEGCO agrees to maintain its turbo generators, boilers, condensers, transformers, and all other associated equipment essential to the operation of Plant in such a manner as to insure operation of all such equipment at full capacity except during periods of outage for inspection and maintenance or as a result of failure of such equipment. Scheduled outages for inspection and maintenance shall be mutually agreed upon the parties hereto. Section 1.05 Delivery Equipment: All necessary equipment at Plant, such as high-voltage switches and metering, communication, telemetering, protective, and load control equipment, including the facilities described in Section 8.01 hereof, required for the delivery of electric capacity and energy as herein provided shall be installed and maintained by SEGCO and shall be included within the term "Plant." Section 1.06 Transmission Lines: In order to deliver electric capacity and energy to Georgia at the delivery points specified in Section 2.01, SEGCO will acquire the necessary right-of-way and construct two single circuit 230 kilovolt lines in accordance with plans and specifications supplied by Georgia from Plant to the Alabama-Georgia state line at points specified by Georgia, said transmission lines being referred to hereinafter as "Transmission Lines." SEGCO agrees to build such additional transmission lines as may be required to transmit electric capacity and energy from Plant to Alabama-Georgia state line as requested by Georgia, and as such transmission lines are constructed they shall be included within the term "Transmission Lines." The above transmission lines will be owned, maintained, and operated by SEGCO. Georgia will construct the necessary transmission lines on the Georgia side of the Alabama-Georgia state line to connect with the lines to be built by SEGCO. Section 1.07 Repair and Replacement of Equipment: In event of failure of any of the facilities or equipment referred to in Section 1.04, Section 1.05, or Section 1.06, SEGCO shall, except as otherwise provided in Section 9.05, repair or replace the same so as to restore it to service as quickly as practicable. Section 1.08 Coal Mines: SEGCO owns coal and coal rights in the Cahaba and Warrior coal fields and agrees to construct and operate coal mines, or provide for such construction and operation by others, to provide a substantial part or all of the fuel required for operation of Plant, any such coal owned by SEGCO and any such coal mines constructed and owned by SEGCO, together will all related mine equipment, being referred to hereinafter as "Coal Mines." Section 1.09 Insurance: SEGCO shall carry insurance on Plant, transmission lines, mining plant and equipment, covering loss or damage, and shall carry insurance covering injury to employees or other persons and damage to property of others; the scope of coverage and amount of insurance to be carried shall be that generally considered as proper and reasonable by electric utility operating companies similarly situated and operating like properties. ARTICLE II DELIVERY OF POWER Section 2.01 Delivery Points: Electric capacity and energy shall be delivered to Alabama at the point or points of connection of the transmission line or lines of Alabama with the 230 kilovolt bus of Plant and electric capacity and energy shall be delivered to Georgia at the points of connection of the transmission lines of SEGCO and Georgia, described in Section 1.06, at the Alabama-Georgia state line. Such point or points are hereby designated and hereinafter referred to as the "delivery points." Title and possession of aforesaid electric capacity and energy shall pas to Alabama and Georgia at their respective delivery points. Section 2.02 Metering: Metering of electric capacity and energy to be delivered to Alabama and Georgia herein referred to shall be at the Plant substation on the low voltage side of the step-transformers, without adjustment for transformation losses and without adjustment for transmission line losses to the delivery points. The flow of electric capacity and energy between the Alabama and Georgia transmission systems across the Plant 230 kilovolt bus shall be metered on said bus. Section 2.03 Interchange at Plant: Since the transmission systems of Alabama and Georgia are already interconnected at several points, there may be a flow of electric capacity and energy between the two systems across the points of interconnection on the high voltage bus of the Plant. This flow of electric capacity and energy together with the difference between the scheduled division of Plant generation between Alabama and Georgia, as described in Section 3.02, and the metered quantities shall be accounted for between Alabama and Georgia under a separate agreement. Section 2.04 Character of Capacity and Energy: The electric capacity and energy to be delivered hereunder shall be of the character commonly known as three-phase alternating current at approximately 60 cycles per second and at a nominal voltage of 230 kilovolts. ARTICLE III USE OF FACILITIES Section 3.01 Allocation of Kilowatt Capacity: One-half of the kilowatt capability of Plant at all times shall be made available to Alabama for scheduling and one-half of such capability shall be made available to Georgia for scheduling. Section 3.02 Scheduling of Plant Generation: Alabama and Georgia shall schedule generation by the Plant within the kilowatt capability available to each, as provided in Section 3.01, limited only the provision that the total generation scheduled at any time shall not be less than the minimum at which the unit or units in service can be safely operated, as specified by SEGCO, and in order to carry out this provision SEGCO may require Alabama and Georgia to schedule their proper share of such minimum generation as determined by rules established by the Supervisory Committee provided for in Section 9.01; provided, however, that either Alabama or Georgia, or both of them, may schedule zero generation for a period of time equal to or longer than the minimum time for which a generating unit can be shut down, as established by SEGCO. In event both Alabama and Georgia schedule zero generation for the same period all generating units at Plant shall be shut down during such period. Subject to the provisions of this Section 3.02, SEGCO will use its best efforts to operate Plant in such a manner as to make the net generation as nearly as a practicable equal to the total generation scheduled by Alabama and Georgia. When Plant net generation is greater or less than the total scheduled by Alabama and Georgia, such generation shall be divided between them in proportion to that scheduled by each. Section 3.03 Kilovolt Amperes: Alabama and Georgia are each entitled to receive one-half of the kilovolt-ampere capability of Plant and in order to enable such deliveries to be made, SEGCO agrees to maintain voltage levels on the 230 Kv bus at Plant as established by the Supervisory Committee and Alabama and Georgia each agree to operate their respective systems and to provide such reactive kilovolt-ampere generating facilities as may be required to hold the flow of reactive kilovolt-amperes into their respective systems within the limit of their entitlements from Plant. ARTICLE IV Rates and Charges Section 4.1: ALABAMA and GEORGIA shall each pay to SEGCO for electric capacity and energy delivered during each month one-half of the rates and charges applicable to plant as determined in accordance with the provisions of Section 4.2 of this Article. In addition, GEORGIA shall pay SEGCO each month the rates and charges applicable to the transmission lines as determined in accordance with the provisions of Section 4.4 of this Article. ALABAMA and GEORGIA shall also pay SEGCO for any costs owed by that particular party to SEGCO for the month for costs associated with Regulated Emissions Allowances that are due by that party pursuant to Article V of this Agreement. ALABAMA and GEORGIA shall become liable to make the payments provided for in this Article commencing on January 1, 1983 and shall continue to be liable to make such payments so long as this agreement remains in full force and effect. Section 4.2: The Monthly Electric Capacity and Energy Charge will be calculated based on the following formula: CEC = [I x (CM + IT)] + E 12 Where CEC = Monthly electric capacity and energy charge which one- half is billed to ALABAMA and one-half is billed to GEORGIA I = Investment CM = Weighted average cost of capital IT = The income tax requirements associated with the common equity weighted cost of capital E = Total current month expense The source of the investment, expense, and cost of capital is as follows: Section 4.3.1: Gross Investment is the total of Federal Energy Regulatory Commission ("FERC") Accounts 301, 310-316, 340-346, 353 and 389-399 at the end of the previous month. Section 4.3.2: Accumulated Depreciation is that depreciation recorded in FERC Account 108 which is associated with the Gross Investment in Section 4.3.1 at the end of the previous month. Section 4.3.3: Net Investment is the difference between Section 4.3.1 (Gross Investment) and Section 4.3.2 (Accumulated Depreciation). Section 4.3.4: Working Capital Deposit is the total amount provided by SEGCO to its agent, ALABAMA, to provide funds for fuel stock, materials and supplies, operation and maintenance expenses, and other expenditures less that portion of the working capital applicable to transmission lines. This amount is taken directly from the books and records of SEGCO. Section 4.3.5 Accumulated Deferred Income Taxes are the net total of FERC Accounts 190, 281, and 283 which are applicable to the investment recorded in FERC Accounts 310-316, 340-346, 353 and 389-399 at the end of the previous month, but excluding amounts recorded in such accounts as a result of the required adoption of SFAS No. 109, such that the required adoption of SFAS No. 109 will have no impact on the amount of the capacity charge. Section 4.3.6 Total Net Investments represents the investment from the summation of Section 4.3.3 (Net Investment) through Section 4.3.5 (Accumulated Deferred Income Taxes) and is the value of "I" in the formula in Section 4.2. Section 4.3.7: Operation and Maintenance Expense is the current month's total of expenses recorded in FERC Accounts 500 through 514 and 546 through 554 plus the applicable O&M expenses in FERC Accounts 560, 562 and 566 through 570 for the generator step-up substation. Section 4.3.8 Administrative and General Expenses, FERC Accounts 920 through 932, excluding Account 924 (Property Insurance) are allocated to plant based on labor charges incurred by ALABAMA on behalf of SEGCO. Account 924 is directly assigned to function and allocated within function based on net investment where direct assignment is not possible. Section 4.3.9: Depreciation Expense is net of Amortization of Investment Tax Credit (AITC). The depreciation expense recorded in FERC Account 403 applicable to the investment recorded in FERC Accounts 310-316, 340-346, 353 and 389-399 is taken directly from the books and records of SEGCO. The AITC is directly assignable to plant or is allocated based on depreciation expense applicable to plant. Section 4.3.10: Real and Personal Property Taxes recorded in FERC Account 408.1 applicable to the investment recorded in FERC Accounts 310-316, 340-346, 353 and 389-399 are assigned directly based on SEGCO's records. Section 4.3.11: State Corporation Franchise Tax recorded in FERC Account 408.1 shall be allocated based on the net investment calculated in Section 4.3.3 and the net investment calculated in Section 4.5.3. Section 4.3.12: Other Taxes - The monthly portion of any taxes other than income taxes recorded in FERC Account 408.1 that may be levied or imposed upon, or payable by SEGCO in the future that is not specified herein will be assigned or allocated based on SEGCO's records. Section 4.3.13: Total Current Month Expense is the summation of Section 4.3.7 (Operation and Maintenance Expense) through Section 4.3.12 (Other Taxes) and is the value for "E" in the formula in Section 4.2. Section 4.3.14: The Cost of Capital and associated income taxes are computed in the following manner: CM = (DR x i) + (ER x C) Where DR + ER = 1.0 IT = T x (ER x C) 1 - T Where T = F + S - 2FS (Federal income taxes applicable for 1 - FS state income tax purposes) CM = Weighted average cost of capital IT = Income tax requirement associated with common weighted cost of capital (Percent) DR = Ratio of debt capital (Actual end of month ratio; includes first mortgage bonds, pollution control obligations, capitalized leases, other long-term debt and notes payable) ER = Ratio of common equity (Actual end of month ratio) i = Embedded cost of debt capital at the end of each month (Percent) C = 11.0%, return on common equity T = Combined state and federal income tax rate F = Federal income tax rate S = State income tax rate Section 4.4: The Monthly Charge on Transmission Lines will be calculated based on the following formula: TC = (I x (CM + IT) + E 12 Where TC = The monthly charge for transmission lines which is billed to GEORGIA I = Investment CM = Weighted average cost of capital IT = The income tax requirement associated with the common equity weighted cost of capital E = Total current month expense Section 4.5.1: Gross Investment is the total of FERC Accounts 350, 352 and 354 through 359 at the end of the previous month. Section 4.5.2: Accumulated Depreciation is that depreciation recorded in FERC Account 108 which is associated with the Gross Investment in Section 4.5.1 at the end of the previous month. Section 4.5.3: Net Investment is the difference between Section 4.5.1 (Gross Investment) and Section 4.5.2 (Accumulated Depreciation). Section 4.5.4: Working Capital Deposit is that portion of the total working capital deposit provided by SEGCO to its agent, ALABAMA, that is for transmission lines. This amount in taken from the books and records of SEGCO. Section 4.5.5: Accumulated Deferred Income Taxes are the net total of FERC Accounts 190, 281, 282 and 283 applicable to the investment recorded in FERC Accounts 350, 352 and 354 through 359 at the end of the previous month. Section 4.5.6: Total Net Investment represents the investment from the summation of Section 4.5.3 (Net Investment) through Section 4.5.5 (Accumulated Deferred Income Taxes) and is the value of "I" in the formula in Section 4.4. Section 4.5.7: Operation and Maintenance Expense is the current month's total of applicable transmission line expenses recorded in FERC Accounts 560, 563 through 568 and 571 through 573. Section 4.5.8: Administrative and General Expenses, FERC Accounts 920 through 932, excluding Account 924 (Property Insurance) are allocated to transmission lines based on labor charges incurred by ALABAMA on behalf of SEGCO. Account 924 is directly assigned to function and allocated within function based on net investment where direct assignment is not possible. Section 4.5.9: Depreciation Expense is net of Amortization of Investment Tax Credit (AITC). The depreciation expense recorded in FERC Account 403 applicable to transmission lines is taken directly from the books and records of SEGCO. The AITC for transmission lines is either directly assignable to transmission lines or is allocated based on depreciation expense applicable to transmission lines. Section 4.5.10: Real and Personal Property Taxes recorded in FERC Account 408.1 applicable to the investment recorded in FERC Accounts 350, 352 and 354 through 359 are assigned directly based on SEGCO's records. Section 4.5.11: State Corporation Franchise Tax recorded in FERC Account 408.1 shall be allocated based on the net investment calculated in Section 4.3.3 and the net investment calculated in Section 4.5.3. Section 4.5.12: Other Taxes - The monthly portion of any taxes other than income taxes recorded in FERC Account 408.1 that may be levied or imposed upon, or payable by SEGCO in the future that is not specified herein will be assigned or allocated based on SEGCO's records. Section 4.5.13: Total Current Month Expense is the summation of Section 4.5.7 (Operation and Maintenance Expense) through Section 4.5.12 (Other Taxes) and is the value of "E" in the formula in Section 4.4. Section 4.5.14: The Cost of Capital and associated income taxes are computed in the following manner: CM = (DR x i) + (ER x C) Where DR + ER = 1.0 IT = T x (ER x C) 1 - T Where T = F + S - 2FS (Federal income taxes applicable 1 - FS for state income tax purposes) CM = Weighted average cost of capital IT = Income tax requirement associated with common weighted cost of capital (Percent)
DR = Ratio of debt capital (Actual end of month ratio; includes first mortgage bonds, pollution control obligations, capitalized leases, other long-term debt and notes payable)
ER = Ratio of common equity (Actual end of month ratio) i = Embedded cost of debt capital at the end of each month (Percent) C = 11.0%, return on common equity T = Combined state and federal income tax rate F = Federal income tax rate S = State income tax rate Section 4.6: Any revision to the Uniform System of Accounts prescribed by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission subsequent to the effective date of this Article will be deemed incorporated into the provisions of this Article as appropriate. ARTICLE V TREATMENT OF EMISSIONS ALLOWANCES Section 5.1: Alabama and Georgia Responsibility for SEGCO Emissions Allowances: Alabama and Georgia shall each bear responsibility for obtaining for SEGCO fifty percent (50%) of the number of emissions allowances (if any) that are necessary under governing law to cover emissions from the SEGCO units for a particular regulated pollutant (e.g., sulfur dioxide ("S02") and nitrogen oxide ("NOx")) ("Regulated Emissions Allowances") minus: (i) the amount of emissions allowances that the SEGCO units are granted/allocated for that pollutant pursuant to governing law for the compliance period at issue plus (ii) the amount of allowances for that pollutant carried over from the previous compliance period plus (iii) emissions allowances for that pollutant otherwise held by or on behalf of SEGCO that are available for its use for that compliance period. An emissions allowance is the right to emit a specified amount of such regulated pollutant during a specified time period. As discussed below, Alabama and Georgia may satisfy their respective responsibilities by paying for, or reimbursing SEGCO for, emissions allowances purchased in the market, by transferring to SEGCO appropriate allowances owned by Alabama or Georgia, or utilizing a combination of the foregoing. Section 5.2 Sulfur Dioxide Emissions Allowances: In accordance with the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 and related laws and regulations ("CAAA"), for each "Annual SO2 Compliance Period," which is an individual calendar year, SEGCO must hold sufficient SO2 emissions allowances ("S02 Allowances") in its SO2 unit accounts ("SO2 Accounts") as part of the SO2 Allowance tracking system regulated by the United States Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") that equal or exceed the amount necessary under the CAAA to cover the total SO2 emissions from the SEGCO units for that time period. Such SO2 Allowances must be in the SO2 Accounts on or before March 1 of the year following the Annual SO2 Compliance Period. For each Annual SO2 Compliance Period, SEGCO is granted a certain number of SO2 Allowances ("Granted SO2 Allowances") for the SEGCO units in accordance with the CAAA. In addition, to the extent that SEGCO had a surplus of SO2 Allowances for the prior Annual SO2 Compliance Period, SEGCO will also have a corresponding number of SO2 Allowances carried forward ("Carried Forward SO2 Allowances") that can be applied, if necessary, to satisfy SEGCO's SO2 Allowance requirements for the Annual SO2 Compliance Period. SEGCO might also have other SO2 Allowances held by it or on its behalf that are available for its use ("Other SO2 Allowances"), including any SO2 Allowances purchased pursuant to Section 5.5. To determine if SEGCO has a sufficient number of SO2 Allowances (Granted SO2 Allowances plus Carried Forward SO2 plus Other SO2 Allowances) to meet or exceed the amount needed to cover the total SO2 emissions from the SEGCO units for the Annual SO2 Compliance Period, SEGCO shall complete a report ("Annual SO2 Reconciliation Report") that will make that determination. SEGCO shall provide the Annual SO2 Reconciliation Report to Alabama and Georgia by January 31 of the year subsequent to the Annual SO2 Compliance Period. If SEGCO has a sufficient number of SO2 Allowances (Granted SO2 Allowances plus Carried Forward SO2 Allowances plus Other SO2 Allowances) to cover its requirements for the Annual SO2 Compliance Period, then SEGCO shall ensure that those SO2 Allowances are in the appropriate SO2 Accounts by March 1 of the year following the Annual SO2 Compliance Period, and no additional action is required under this Section 5.2 by Alabama or Georgia for that time period. If the Annual SO2 Reconciliation Report establishes that SEGCO does not have sufficient SO2 Allowances in its SO2 Accounts for the Annual SO2 Compliance Period, then Alabama and Georgia shall each be responsible for obtaining and/or providing fifty percent (50%) of the additional SO2 Allowances that are necessary for SEGCO to have a sufficient number of SO2 Allowances in its SO2 Account to cover, at a minimum, the total SO2 emissions from the SEGCO units. In such an instance, Alabama and Georgia each shall, within five (5) business days of receipt of the Annual SO2 Reconciliation Report, provide written notice to SEGCO regarding the method in which the party shall satisfy its obligation. Alabama and Georgia's alternatives are: (A) Purchase: the party may direct SEGCO to purchase from the over-the-counter emissions markets sufficient SO2 Allowances to satisfy the party's SO2 Allowance responsibility for the Annual SO2 Compliance Period. In such an instance, the amount that the party will owe will be based upon the Cantor Fitzgerald Allowance price, or such other index price as mutually agreed by the parties should the Cantor Fitzgerald index become unavailable, for the month of February (published on or about January 25th) following the Annual SO2 Compliance Period for the immediate settlement (sale) of 2,500 SO2 Allowances from the market, together with all transaction costs (as defined below) associated with the purchase of such Allowances; (B) Like-Kind Transfer: the party may transfer to SEGCO, by no later than the 10th business day of February of the year following the Annual SO2 Compliance Period, a sufficient number of SO2 Allowances held by the party to satisfy its SO2 Allowance responsibility for the Annual SO2 Compliance Period (a "Like-Kind Transfer"); or (C) Combination of Purchase and Like-Kind Transfer: the party may use a combination of purchase of SO2 Allowances from the over-the-counter emissions markets and Like-Kind Transfer to satisfy that party's S02 Allowance responsibility. Alabama and Georgia may choose different alternatives for the same Annual SO2 Compliance Period. If a party fails to provide notice of its choice within the specified 5 business day period, then it shall be deemed to have chosen alternative (A). If purchase is utilized under either alternative (A) or (C), then the costs of such purchase will be included in the party's monthly charge, in accordance with Article IV. SO2 Allowances are not divisible. If the Annual SO2 Reconciliation Report establishes that an odd number of additional SO2 Allowances are necessary for SEGCO to have a sufficient number of SO2 Allowances in its SO2 Accounts for the Annual SO2 Compliance Period, then Alabama and Georgia shall each bear responsibility for fifty percent (50%) of the number of evenly divisible additional SO2 Allowances. For the single, remaining SO2 Allowance, SEGCO, in its discretion, shall determine how that SO2 Allowance shall be acquired (including by Like-Kind Transfer) and/or purchased and which party(ies) shall bear responsibility for such an acquisition and/or purchase. Section 5.3 Nitrous Oxide Emissions Allowances: In accordance with the NOx Budget Training Program (40 C.F.R. Part 96, 40 CFR ? 51.121), for each May through September time period ("Ozone Season") beginning on May 31, 2004, SEGCO must hold sufficient NOx emissions allowances ("NOx Allowances") in its Nitrogen Oxide Allowance Trading System ("NATS") accounts, administered by the EPA, that equal or exceed the amount necessary to cover the total NOx emissions from the SEGCO units for that Ozone Season. Such NOx Allowances must be in the NATS accounts on or before November 30 following the end of each Ozone Season. For each Ozone Season, SEGCO is granted a certain number of NOx Allowances ("Granted NOx Allowances") for the SEGCO units in accordance with the NOx Budget Trading Program. In addition, to the extent that SEGCO had a surplus of NOx Allowances for the prior Ozone Season, SEGCO will also have a corresponding number of NOx Allowances carried forward ("Carried Forward NOx Allowances") that can be applied, if necessary, to satisfy SEGCO's NOx Allowance requirements for the Ozone Season. SEGCO might also have NOx Allowances held by it or others that are available for its use ("Other NOx Allowances), including any NOx Allowances purchased pursuant to Section 5.5. To determine if SEGCO has a sufficient number of NOx Allowances (Granted NOx Allowances plus Carried Forward NOx Allowances plus Other NOx Allowances) to meet or exceed the amount of NOx emissions from the SEGCO units for the Ozone Season, SEGCO shall complete a report ("Ozone Season NOx Reconciliation Report") that will make that determination. SEGCO shall provide the Ozone Season NOx Reconciliation Report to Alabama and Georgia by October 31 following the end of the Ozone Season. If SEGCO has a sufficient number of NOx Allowances (Granted NOx Allowances plus Carried Forward NOx Allowances plus Other NOx Allowances) to cover its requirements for the Ozone Season, then SEGCO shall ensure that those Ozone Allowances are in the appropriate NATS accounts by November 30 following the Ozone Season, and no additional action is required under this Section 5.3 by Alabama or Georgia for that time period. If the Ozone Season NOx Reconciliation Report establishes that SEGCO does not have a sufficient number of NOx Allowances in its NATS accounts for the Ozone Season, then Alabama and Georgia shall each be responsible for obtaining and/or providing fifty percent (50%) of the additional NOx Allowances that are necessary for SEGCO to have a sufficient number of NOx Allowances in its NATs accounts to, at a minimum, cover the total NOx emissions from the SEGCO units. In such an instance, Alabama and Georgia each shall, within five (5) business days of receipt of the Ozone Season NOx Reconciliation Report, provide written notice to SEGCO regarding the method in which the party shall satisfy its obligation. Alabama and Georgia's alternatives are: (A) Purchase: the party may direct SEGCO to purchase from the over-the-counter emissions markets sufficient NOx Allowances to satisfy the party's NOx Allowance responsibility for the Ozone Season. In such instance, the amount that the party will owe will be the average price of the most current bid and offer price for the tenth (10th) business day of the October following the end of the Ozone Season as published in the Evolution Express Market Price Report created daily by Evolution Markets LLC, or such other index price as mutually agreed by the parties should the Evolution Express Market Price report become unavailable, together with all transaction costs (as defined below) associated with purchase of such allowances; (B) Like-Kind Transfer: the party may transfer, by no later than the tenth (10th) business day of November following the end of the Ozone Season, to SEGCO a sufficient number of NOx Allowances held by the party to satisfy its NOx Allowance responsibility for the Ozone Season (a "Like-Kind Transfer"); or (C) Combination of Purchase and Like-Kind Transfer: the party may use a combination of purchase of NOx Allowances from the over-the-counter emissions markets and Like-Kind Transfer to satisfy that party's NOx Allowance responsibility. Alabama and Georgia may choose different alternatives for the same Ozone Season. If a party fails to provide notice of its choice within the specified 5 business day period, then it shall be deemed to have chosen alternative (A). If purchase is utilized under either alternative (A) or (C), then the costs of such purchase will be included in the party's monthly charge, in accordance with Article IV. NOx Allowances are not divisible. If the Annual NOx Reconciliation Report establishes that an odd number of additional NOx Allowances are necessary for SEGCO to have a sufficient number of NOx Allowances in its NATS accounts for the Ozone Season, then Alabama and Georgia shall each bear responsibility for fifty percent (50%) of the number of evenly divisible additional NOx Allowances. For the single, remaining NOx Allowance, SEGCO, in its discretion, shall determine how that NOx Allowance shall be acquired (including by Like-Kind Transfer) and/or purchased and which party(ies) shall bear responsibility for such an acquisition and/or purchase. Section 5.4 Other Regulated Emissions Allowances Programs: If additional or revised emissions allowances programs and restrictions become governing law after the adoption of this Article V, the parties intend that responsibilities, procedures, alternatives, and cost responsibilities similar, if not identical, to those provided in Sections 5.2 and 5.3 shall apply for any such additional or revised emissions allowances program. In particular, the parties intend that the following shall apply to the extent reasonably feasible Following the end of the compliance period for the particular regulated pollutant, SEGCO shall complete a report ("Annual Regulated Emissions Reconciliation Report") that will determine if SEGCO has a sufficient number of emissions allowances for that regulated pollutant to satisfy the requirements of governing law. SEGCO shall provide the Annual Regulated Emissions Reconciliation Report to Alabama and Georgia within 31 days of the end of that compliance period if time permits under that emissions allowance program. If the compliance deadline for SEGCO to have a sufficient number of emissions allowances in an appropriate account does not reasonably permit SEGCO such a 31 day time period to prepare that report or to comply with other deadlines discussed in this Section 5.4, then SEGCO shall have such shorter time period(s) as determined by agreement of the parties. If SEGCO has a sufficient number of emissions allowances for that pollutant to cover its requirements for the compliance period, then SEGCO shall ensure that those allowances are in the appropriate accounts by the deadline required under governing law, and no additional action is required under this Section 5.4 by Alabama or Georgia for that compliance period. If the Annual Regulated Emissions Reconciliation Report establishes that SEGCO does not have sufficient emissions allowances for that compliance period, then Alabama and Georgia shall each be responsible for obtaining and/or providing fifty percent (50%) of the additional emissions allowances that are necessary for SEGCO to have a sufficient number of emissions allowances in the appropriate account to, at a minimum, cover the total emissions of that regulated pollutant from the SEGCO units for the compliance period. In such an instance, Alabama and Georgia each shall, within five (5) business days of receipt of the Annual Regulated Emissions Reconciliation Report, provide written notice to SEGCO regarding the method in which the party shall satisfy its obligation. Alabama and Georgia's alternatives are: (A) Purchase: the party may direct SEGCO to purchase from the over-the-counter emissions markets sufficient emissions allowances to satisfy the party's responsibility under this Section 5.4 for that compliance period; (B) Like-Kind Transfer: the party may transfer by, no later than ten (10) business days after receiving the Annual Regulated Emissions Reconciliation Report, to SEGCO a sufficient number of emission allowances held by the party to satisfy the its responsibility under this Section 5.4 for that compliance period (a "Like-Kind Transfer"); or (C) Combination of Purchase and Like-Kind Transfer: the party may use a combination of purchase of emissions allowances from the over-the-counter emissions markets and Like-Kind Transfer to satisfy that party's emissions allowance responsibility under this Section 5.4. Alabama and Georgia may choose different alternatives for the same compliance period. If a party fails to provide notice of its choice within the specified 5 business day period, then it shall be deemed to have chosen alternative (A). If purchase is utilized under either alternative (A) or (C), then the costs of such purchase will be included in the party's monthly charge, in accordance with Article IV. If an emissions allowance for the regulated pollutant should not be equally divisible, and should the Annual Regulated Emissions Reconciliation Report establishes that an odd number of additional emissions allowances are necessary for SEGCO to have a sufficient number of emissions allowances in the appropriate accounts for that compliance period, then Alabama and Georgia shall each bear responsibility for fifty percent (50%) of the number of evenly divisible additional allowances. For the single, remaining emissions allowance, SEGCO, in its discretion, shall determine how that emissions allowance shall be acquired (including by transfer) and/or purchased and which party shall bear responsibility for such acquisition and/or purchase. Section 5.5 Purchase of Regulated Emissions Allowances Throughout the Year: Alabama and Georgia authorize SEGCO to purchase Regulated Emissions Allowances throughout the year so as to take advantage of economic opportunities within the emissions markets. Any such purchased emissions allowances shall be placed into the appropriate SEGCO account for that regulated pollutant (e.g., SO2 Account, NATS account). Alabama and Georgia shall each bear responsibility for fifty percent (50%) of the costs for any such allowances, including all commercially reasonable transaction costs related thereto and all carrying costs related thereto. As used herein, "transaction costs" may include, without limitation, commissions, legal fees, administrative expenses properly allocable to the transaction, and any other cost or expense items that would not otherwise have been incurred by SEGCO absent the allowance purchase activity performed hereunder. As used herein, "carrying costs" shall mean the application of the Cost of Capital, as defined in Section 4.5.14, to the costs of any such purchase and transaction costs for the time period between the purchase and the use of those emissions allowances. These costs shall be included in the parties' respective monthly charges, in accordance with Article IV. Section 5.6 Compliance with Emissions Allowances Laws: Regardless of Alabama and Georgia's responsibilities under this Article V, SEGCO shall take appropriate action to ensure compliance with all governing laws pertaining to Regulated Emissions Allowances. For any such cost not specifically allocated to Alabama and/or Georgia under this Article V, the resulting costs shall be borne: (i) by Alabama or Georgia to the extent such costs are directly attributable to that party and/or (ii) equally by Alabama and Georgia to the extent not recovered under (i) above. Any such costs shall be included in Alabama and/or Georgia's respective monthly charge in accordance with Article IV. However, if any such action necessary to comply with such laws is due solely to compensate for any failure of either Alabama or Georgia to fulfill any of their respective duties under this Article V, then SEGCO shall bill that party directly for the costs of such action. In particular, if Alabama or Georgia commits to a Like-Kind Transfer but fails to provide such emissions allowances by the appointed date, then SEGCO may purchase such allowances by any commercially means available to them. In that event, SEGCO will invoice the party the sum of the following: i) the cost of purchasing a sufficient quantity of allowances to cover the deficiency; and (ii) transactions costs (described above). ARTICLE VI MINIMUM PAYMENTS Section 6.01 Payments: Subject to the provisions of Section 6.03 and notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in Section 9.06 or in any of the other provisions of this Agreement, Alabama and Georgia, for the right hereby granted to purchase power and energy, will pay or cause to be paid, from time to time, commencing with the date the first unit at Plant is declared available for commercial operation or January 1, 1961, whichever is earlier, in the respective percentages set forth in Section 6.02, whether or not SEGCO shall have any power and energy available, amounts sufficient to provide SEGCO with funds which, together with all other available funds of SEGCO, including funds received pursuant to Article IV, if any, and funds available under the construction fund provided for in the mortgage (as hereinafter defined), if any, will be sufficient to enable SEGCO to meet when due all its operating and other expenses, if any, all its taxes, if any, the interest payments on all construction fund bonds (as hereinafter defined) that may be outstanding from time to time under the mortgage, if any, its obligations under any sinking fund for the construction fund bonds that may be provided for in the mortgage, if any, and its obligations under any renewal and replacement fund, if any, provided for in the mortgage for the benefit of construction fund bonds. The term "operating and other expenses" shall not include any payments on the principal of indebtedness, whether at stated or accelerated maturity. The term "mortgage" shall mean that indenture of mortgage which shall constitute a first mortgage lien, subject only to such prior liens as may be permitted therein, on Plant, Transmission Lines and Coal Mines. The term "construction fund bonds" shall mean all bonds issued under and secured by the mortgage, the proceeds of which were deposited in the construction fund to be provided for in the mortgage and any indebtedness issued on the basis of, or to provide for, the payment of any such bonds. Section 6.02 Percentages: In the performance of the obligations imposed by Section 6.01, Alabama shall be obligated to pay a percentage equal to the apportionment percentage (as hereinafter defined) and Georgia shall be obligated to pay a percentage equal to one hundred (100) percent minus the apportionment percentage, of any amount required to be paid pursuant to Section 6.01. The term "apportionment percentage" shall mean the percentage equal to that obtained by dividing an amount equal to one half (1/2) the total amount shown on the books of SEGCO as its investment in Plant and Coal Mines at the end of the previous month by an amount equal to the sum of the amounts shown by the books of SEGCO for investment in Plant, Transmission Lines, and Coal Mines as of the same date, after deducting, in each case, the amount of any then applicable depreciation or depletion reserves on the books of SEGCO. For the purpose of this paragraph the amount of investment in Plant, Transmission Lines and Coal Mines, and the amount of any reserves applicable thereto, shall be determined on the basis of the character of the actual expenditures made without regard to whether or not such expenditures at the time are recorded in functional plant accounts or in an unsegregated account, such as construction work in progress, in Account 141 of the Federal Power Commission's Uniform System of Accounts, and, in the case of reserves, on the basis of the amounts last theretofore recorded in functional reserve accounts. Section 6.03 Nature of Obligations: The obligations of Alabama and Georgia under this Article VI shall be several, separate and distinct and shall not be joint or joint and several. Section 6.04 Waiver of Defenses: Alabama and Georgia each hereby irrevocably waives any defense based on the adequacy of a remedy at law which might be asserted as a bar to the remedy of specific performance in any action brought against either for the specific performance of this Agreement by SEGCO, by any assignee of SEGCO, or by any receiver or trustee appointed for SEGCO under the bankruptcy or insolvency laws of any jurisdiction to which SEGCO is subject; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall be deemed to constitute a representation or warranty by Alabama or Georgia that the obligation of such company under this Agreement is, as a matter of law, subject to the equitable remedy of specific performance. Section 6.05 Term of Obligation Hereunder: The obligations to make payments under this Article VI shall commence at the time herein specified and shall, so long as SEGCO shall not be willfully in default in the performance of its obligations under Section 1.01 hereof, continue until there shall be deposited with the trustee or trustees under the mortgage an amount which, together with all amounts available to the trustee or trustees for the purpose, shall be sufficient to redeem or pay at maturity all construction fund bonds at the time outstanding under the mortgage, together with interest thereon as provided therein and in the mortgage. SEGCO shall in no case be considered to be willfully in default in the performance of any of its obligations under Section 1.01 owed to a party hereto at any time during which such party controls (SEGCO or is under common control with SEGCO. For the purposes of the foregoing provision, the term "control" means the possession, direct or indirect, of the legal power (which is then being exercised) to determine and control the management of the business of a person, whether through the ownership of voting securities, by contract, or otherwise. ARTICLE VII BILLING AND PAYMENT Section 7.01 Presentation and Payment: SEGCO shall render to Alabama and to Georgia on or about the tenth day of each month a written bill for the respective amounts due it under the provisions of Article IV for the preceding calendar month and shall render bills to Alabama and Georgia for any amounts due it under the provisions of Article VI as may be required. All such bills shall be due and payable within fifteen (15) days after rendition. Section 7.02 Statements, Audits, and Inspection: SEGCO shall furnish to Alabama and to Georgia statements in reasonable detail as to all items entering into the determination of charges certified by an officer of SEGCO. SEGCO shall furnish to Alabama and to Georgia annually a copy of an audit of its books and accounts for the preceding year made by an independent auditor. Alabama and Georgia shall have access at reasonable intervals to the books and records of SEGCO and shall have access to the Plant for the purpose of inspection. Upon the delivery or receipt of any such statements or audits, all parties to this Agreement shall have four (4) months within which to complete a check thereof, but if none of the parties within such four months' period shall make a request for correction, such statements or audits shall be conclusive on all parties as to the facts therein set forth. Section 7.03 Disputed Bill: If either Alabama or Georgia shall, in good faith, dispute any bill so rendered, then within the period fixed in Section 7.01 for the payment of the same the party or parties disputing such bill shall pay SEGCO the amount charged without any deduction or set-off which might be claimed, but shall set forth the basis of its contentions. If the parties thereafter cannot agree on the correctness of the bill in question, the dispute shall be submitted to arbitration as hereinafter provided. If, as a result of such arbitration, SEGCO must refund any part of the moneys thus paid by Alabama or Georgia, SEGCO shall forthwith make such payment, together with interest at the rate of six (6.0) percent per annum from the date of payment of such moneys to it. Subject to the provisions of Section 7.02, Alabama or Georgia may, notwithstanding any of the foregoing provisions of this Section 7.03, before or after payment, dispute the correctness of any charges made on a bill rendered pursuant to Section 7.01. Section 7.04 Remedies: If either Alabama or Georgia shall fail to pay any bill within the time above allowed, SEGCO may, at its option, suspend the delivery of electric capacity and energy hereunder to the party defaulting such payment until all moneys due it have been paid, together with interest at the rate of six (6.0) percent per annum, said interest to run from the time such payment was due, to wit: the 15th day after the rendition of such bill. This right of suspension is in addition to all other rights at law, in equity or under this Agreement which SEGCO may have in the circumstances, and the exercise thereof, or of any such rights in law, in equity or under this Agreement, shall not be deemed to impair or abrogate this Agreement in any way, and such right may be exercised whenever and as often as any such default in payment of bills shall occur, and any delay or omission on the part of SEGCO to exercise any right to it accruing in the case of default shall not be a deemed a waiver of any rights hereunder or to which it might have recourse at law of in equity. ARTICLE VIII METERING Section 8.01 Metering Equipment: SEGCO shall provide at the Plant such metering equipment as may be necessary to measure accurately the electric capacity and energy to be furnished hereunder. Said metering equipment, including generator and station service meters, shall at all times be kept accurate within one (1.0) percent and SEGCO shall read all meters once every hour. All metering equipment shall be of a make and type to be agreed upon by the Supervisory Committee. All meters pertaining to billing shall be sealed and shall be opened in the presence of an authorized representative of each party hereto and all such meters shall be tested by such representatives upon request of any party hereto, but at least once every six months. If, as a result of such tests, any metering equipment shall be found to be inaccurate, it shall be restored to a condition of accuracy or replaced by new equipment satisfactory to the Supervisory Committee. If the inaccuracy of any metering equipment shall exceed one (1.0) percent, then the readings of meters previously taken, and all charges based thereon, shall be corrected on the basis of said tests, but not for more than thirty (30) days prior to the date of test, nor prior to the date within such thirty (30) days upon which such equipment has been proven or agreed to be accurate and in the event of stoppage of a meter, the amount of electric capacity and energy furnished during the period of such stoppage shall be determined from any meter reading or other data which may be available and applicable for the purpose, and such determination shall be used for billing hereunder; provided that, in the event of any disagreement between the parties hereto with respect to such corrections to or estimates of metered quantities, such disagreement shall be referred to arbitrators as provided in Section 10.01. Section 8.02 Records: SEGCO shall keep in quadruplicate a continuous log record of the operation of Plant on which shall be recorded at the end of every one (1) hour period the readings of all meters and instruments pertaining to the delivery of and billing for electric capacity and energy furnished to Alabama and to Georgia hereunder. There shall also be recorded in such records a brief statement giving complete detailed facts insofar as possible as to any interruptions or other unusual events affecting service. A complete set of said records shall be made each day to Alabama, to Georgia, and to any person designated the Supervisory Committee. Section 8.03 Disagreement: In event such records supplied by SEGCO are unsatisfactory to Alabama or to Georgia, any question arising with the respect thereto shall be taken up for adjustment between the parties within sixty (60) days from the mailing of such records or any objection or disagreement shall be deemed to have been waived without prejudice to the right of Alabama or Georgia to dispute any similar data or statements in the future. ARTICLE IX MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS Section 9.01 Supervisory Committee: Alabama, Georgia, and SEGCO shall each appoint one representative to act for it in connection with this Agreement, said representatives being referred to collectively as the "Supervisory Committee." Evidence of such appointment shall be given by written notice by each of the parties to the other two parties and such representatives may be changed at any time by similar notice. The Supervisory Committee, in addition to matters specifically referred to elsewhere in this Agreement, shall be responsible for establishing rules for scheduling plant generation as provided in Section 3.02; for determining meter arrangements; coordinating communication facilities, settings of relays, telemetering, the tie line load control; establishing operating practices for guidance of load dispatchers and other operating employees of the parties as to matters affecting the delivery of power hereunder; establishing the procedure to be followed in accounting for the flow of power to be delivered hereunder; and other similar operating matters; provided, however, that all administrative matters such as sources and costs of fuel, personnel policies, rates of pay, working conditions, and all similar matters related to Plant not provided for herein, shall be the sole responsibility of SEGCO. The Supervisory Committee shall have the authority to appoint an agent to act in its behalf and said agent shall be responsible to said Supervisory Committee. Section 9.02 Responsibility and Indemnification: SEGCO shall not be responsible for electric capacity and energy after its delivery to Alabama or to Georgia at the respective delivery points. Each party hereto expressly agrees to indemnify and save harmless and defend the others against all claims, demands, costs, or expense for loss, damage, or injury to persons or property, in any manner directly or indirectly connected with or growing out of the generation, transmission, or use of electric capacity and energy on its own side of the delivery point or points hereunder; provided, however, that each party hereto shall in all cases be responsible for any liability under the provisions of any applicable workmen's compensation law for damage or injury to its own employees and will not seek any reimbursement therefor from any other party. Section 9.03 Operating Instructions: SEGCO agrees to comply with the reasonable instructions of the Supervisory Committee established under Section 9.01 with regard to loading of Plant and the operation of switches and other apparatus controlling the electric capacity and energy to be supplied hereunder. Section 9.04 Notice of Failure: In event of the failure of or damage to any apparatus at Plant affecting service rendered hereunder, SEGCO shall give immediate notice to Alabama's and to Georgia's load dispatching offices and to any person designated by the Supervisory Committee. Section 9.05 Destruction of Plant: In event that Plant is destroyed or demolished or damaged to the extent that it is practically destroyed, whether such destruction is by fire, explosion, flood, earthquake, enemy action, riot, mob action, or otherwise, so as to prevent SEGCO from carrying out the provisions of this Agreement in accordance with its true intent and meaning; then, and in such case, SEGCO, Alabama or Georgia shall have the option to cancel the provisions of this Agreement, except for provisions of Article VI and Section 9.11, forthwith upon written notice of intention to so cancel; provided, however, that such notice must be given within sixty (60) days after the happening of the event causing the destruction, demolition, or damage. The parties hereto agree that the provisions of Article VI and Section 9.11 shall continue in full force and effect until terminated as provided for Article VI, irrespective of any cancellation pursuant to this Section 9.05. Section 9.06 Force Majeure: Except as otherwise provided in Section 6.01 hereof, in case any party hereto should be delayed in or prevented from performing or carrying out any of the agreements, covenants, and obligations made by and imposed upon said parties, or any of them, by this Agreement by reason of or through strike, stoppage in labor, failure of contractors or suppliers of materials, riot, fire, flood, ice, invasion, civil war, commotion, insurrection, military or usurped power, order of any Court or Judge granted in any bona fide adverse legal proceedings or action, order of any civil or military authority either de facto or de jure, explosion, act of God or the public enemies, or any cause reasonably beyond its control and not attributable to its neglect; then, and in such case or cases, such party shall not be liable to any other party for or on account of any loss, damage, injury, or expense resulting from or arising out of such delay or prevention, and such period of delay or prevention shall not be reckoned or accounted as a part of the time during which such party was to perform and carry out the same; provided, however, that the party suffering such delay or prevention shall use due and, in its judgment, practicable diligence to remove the cause or causes thereof, and any party claiming an extension of time hereunder shall immediately give written notice of such claim to the other parties. Section 9.07 Regulation: The parties recognize the fact that this Agreement, or part or parts thereof, or changes or alterations therein, or action or actions to be taken pursuant thereto, may be or may become subject to the valid regulatory jurisdiction of certain authorized agencies of the Federal Government and of the states of Alabama and Georgia. Section 9.08 Term of Agreement: This Agreement shall continue in effect until the 31st day of May, 1996, and thereafter shall be automatically extended for succeeding periods of two (2) years, unless terminated by any party to this Contract upon two (2) years written notice to the other parties to this Contract, provided; however, that the provisions of Article VI and of Section 9.11 shall continue in full force and effect in accordance with the terms of Article VI. Section 9.09 Assignability: This Agreement shall bind the parties hereto, their successors and assigns, but no assignment hereof shall in any event relieve Alabama, Georgia, or SEGCO of any of their obligations hereunder. Section 9.10 Revision of Rate of Return: The parties hereto agree to revise from time to time, subject to the provisions of Article VI and of Section 9.07, the rate of return on investment provided for in this Agreement so that said rate of return to be thereafter applied for the purposes of this Agreement shall approximately correspond to the rate of return to which SEGCO would be entitled, at such time, in the judgment of the parties, under then applicable rate-regulatory principles relating to similar businesses and investments. In the event at any time any party shall request that a revision shall be made in accordance with the foregoing provisions, and the parties are unable to agree within six months of such request on the rate of return to be thereafter applied, then such question shall be determined by arbitration pursuant to Article X. Section 9.11 Change or Alteration of the Agreement: This Agreement may be changed or altered only by an agreement in writing signed by all the parties hereto; provided that, so long as Article VI shall be by its terms effective and so long as this Agreement shall be pledged under the mortgage, no such change or alteration shall be effected except upon compliance with applicable provisions of the mortgage. Section 9.12 Agreement to be Pledged Under Mortgage: The parties hereto agree that this Agreement shall be assigned to and pledged with the trustee or trustees under the mortgage, to be held as part of the trust estate under and subject to all the terms of the mortgage. ARTICLE X ARBITRATION Section 10.01 Arbitration: Any dispute hereunder arising over a question of fact shall be submitted to three arbitrators, none of whom shall be an agent or employee of any party to this Agreement, with one arbitrator being selected by each of the three parties to this Agreement; provided, however, that if one of the parties shall fail or neglect for a period of ten (10) days after receipt of written notice by another of the parties to select an arbitrator upon its part, the arbitrators selected by the other two parties shall select a third arbitrator, or in event two of the parties fail or neglect to select arbitrators on their behalf within ten (10) days after receipt of written notice by the third party to this Agreement, the arbitrator appointed by the party giving such notice shall select another arbitrator, and the two thus chosen shall select a third. The three arbitrators thus chosen shall proceed to hear and determine the matter in dispute and a decision of the majority of the three shall be final and binding; provided, however, that each of the parties hereto shall be given at least ten (10) days' written notice prior to the hearing of any matter submitted to such Board of Arbitrators. The arbitrators' fees and the expense of arbitration shall be divided among the parties hereto as directed by the arbitrators. The parties to this Agreement covenant with each other to abide by the decision of the arbitrators selected hereunder. IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties hereto have caused this Agreement to be executed under seal in three counterparts, each of which shall be considered an original, pursuant to authority of resolutions of their respective boards of directors. Attest: SOUTHERN ELECTRIC GENERATING COMPANY /s/ W.D. Ketchum /s/ J.F. Crist Secretary President
Attest: ALABAMA POWER COMPANY /s/ Charles P. Jackson /s/ Walter Bouldin Secretary President
Attest: GEORGIA POWER COMPANY /s/ E.C. Hammond /s/ J.J. McDonough Secretary President
